title: Girl, 4, nearly dies after contracting E.coli following trip to zoo
text:
Isla Grainger, four, was seriously ill (Picture: Solent News)

A girl spent 17 days in hospital after contracting a potentially fatal infection following a visit to a petting zoo.

Isla Grainger, four, had to be put into an induced coma in intensive care after an E.coli bug infection caused her kidneys to fail.

She got so ill after visiting Tapnell Farm, in Yarmouth on the Isle of Wight, with her family that her mum Lauren Aspery, 21, described her condition as a ‘matter of life and death’.

Ms Asprey, who lives in Whiteley, near Fareham, Hertfordshire, took her daughter to the emergency department at Southampton General Hospital when she stopped eating and struggled to go to the toilet for three days.

Isla, who also had diarrhoea and sickness, then had emergency surgery to insert a catheter and started urgent dialysis, with a stool sample showing E.coli O157 was present.

Isla in hospital after being put into a coma (Picture: Solent)

Isla spent 17 days in the hospital (Picture: Solent)

After coming around, Isla began her recovery with dialysis and medication.

Ms Aspery, who works for a mortgage company, said: ‘It was terrifying. I thought the worst and that we were going to lose our little girl.

‘I really believed this was just a bad case of sickness.

‘The doctor took a breath and told us that ‘Isla is very very poorly, much more sick than we thought’.

Isla is doing much better now but cannot yet return to school (Picture: Solent)

Ms Asprey, who also had painful stomach aches and nausea after the holiday, said Isla would most likely face problems in the future when she hits puberty and pregnancy and her prognosis is still unknown.

She added: ‘I was so pleased we had an answer and knew what has caused the failure but I’m very concerned that we are yet to find out where the E.coli was contracted from and there is a high chance other people can be putting themselves at risk.’

A spokeswoman for Tapnell Farm said the team wished Isla a ‘speedy recovery’.

Public Health England said its investigation into the source of the infection is ongoing.

E.coli is a bacteria found in the gut and faeces of many animals, particularly cattle, and can be caught by eating contaminated food, touching infected animals and contact with people who have the illness.

description: A toddler spent 17 days in hospital after contracting a potentially fatal infection after visiting a petting zoo.
